commentBody: all the proper nouns wore me down.

Enjoyed this one, especially all the Js, Qs, Xs, etc. Also the constructor's notes--I'm always curious about how a puzzle came to be.

I've been out of the country a lot this fall and not keeping up with things--but it's good to get caught up (sort of) and back to puzzling.
My fastest Saturday yet--THX!

A double pangram is a fine accomplishment, and I commend Blake for the effort. Personally, I like a bit more wordplay in a Saturday, and while I'm all for knowing things, the PPP level today was a bit high even for me. I would have preferred a single pangram and a bit more puzzling. But WHATEVS.

YMMV.
Two squares I wasn‚Äôt sure about so I had to try different permutations of the various letters till I got it. RFK not jFK. VEZ not ViZ. Cute puzzle. Quick.
Four obscure (to me, admittedly) proper names in the northeast corner alone? C'mon!

This one gave me a nice workout without frustrating me, although I must admit I cheated.  When I saw the clue referring to Cloud Cuckoo Land, I instinctively looked up to the bookshelf that sits behind the chair where I sit to do the puzzle, to glean the name DOERR from the spine of All The Light We Cannot See without actually seeing if I could remember his name all on my own.  Both books, by the way are wonderful, and quite different from each other.

I suspect the crossings of ORAJEL, DIETPEPSI, and ERASERMATE will vex some.  I got them all via crosses, so I‚Äôm not complaining, although that did seem a bit much for me.

I loved the clue, cab driver, for WINESELLER and smiled to see it crossed by ZINN.  I also smiled to see my old crossword friend ELIA who was a crossword staple of the puzzles of my younger days and who I can‚Äôt recall seeing in a while

I make a mean lamb KORMA but I‚Äôve never ventured to make ROTI.

What a superbly unenjoyable puzzle üòê

The natick of RENAT_/_R_JEL/E_ZYE was just ab5urd. A rapper's name can be anything, as well as an American brand. RENATa (a quite popular Polish name) seems just as viable as RENATO (actually, even more so to me).

I also don't speak Spanish. I know some of it from hearing, mostly. I happily entered OTRA VEs. That final "s" crossed with the name of some guy which I ended up googling. ZINN... OTRA VE*Z*... Crossing a non-English entry with a name you can't possibly infer if you don't simply know it. How is this good construction?

MARL_/D_ERR... How the fiddly fiddle was I supposed to deal with that without Google? Wouldn't you expect an actress to rather be called MARLa than MARLO? DaERR looks no worse than DOERR to me.

To add insuIt to injury, there was a mathematical clue ü§¨

The puzzle was generally saturated with crossing trivia, which I just can't personally abide. I want witty clues and misdirection, not a flippin' pub trivia quiz.
Proper nounanza.

Some disparate thoughts: Again, they seem to have mixed up the Friday and Saturday offerings. My time was about 2/3 what it was on the Friday puzzle, and according to xwstats.com, at least so far, the Friday median time was almost double the Saturday. I think Caitlin meant that Q, J and X are repeated in the same entries, not Q, J and Z. The constructor set out to create a double pangram, which is a coup for him, but fairly meaningless for the solver. I'm not sure I can be all that impressed, anyway. The record for multiple pangrams is a quintuple, on Wed., 8/10/16, by David C. Duncan Dekker. Here's the completed grid (go to the Archive if you'd rather solve): https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=8/10/2016 In that puzzle, 130 out of 195 letters contributed to making it a 5x pangram. That left very little else to play with! Plus, he managed to fit QUINTUPLE and FIVEFOLD in as entries. I thought 1A was going to be about the NYC subway, but 843 seems like a few too many stops. 18A: I gave some thought to the historian being Howard FAST. 63A: The other day KAYO, today TKOS. I don't think we'll see TEE KAYOS. 14A: Did anyone else have -UID------ and assume it was going to be "guide" something? 33A: Charles DOLAN is a very local NYC name. 25D: Though the answer is technically correct, IDAHO is a state, CANADA a country. Would cluing it to British Columbia be too easy?

difficult trivia. obscure proper names. The worst clue was sprinkles with oil. I thought dress as a salad. I never heard of anything being blessed by sprinkling oil. Must be a rite I am unfamiliar with. You anoint with oil but sprinkle? no.
‚ÄúEnd of a set, in mathematics‚Äù is not the upper bound. An upper bound is any value larger than any member of a set.

I was doing pretty well for a Saturday until I got to that renamed bridge. Guessed it was JFK, making the little cars JCCARS. Tried RFK and RCCARS but still no happy message, because I'd forgotten I'd plugged in a Y (MARLy/DyERR) as a guess for those two names. Grr. 

I've looked it up. If anyone else was stumped, RC CARS are radio controlled cars.
I‚Äôm always excited for a Saturday pizza and grateful to the creators. But I‚Äôm here today to kvetch - Two different sets of down/across clues leading to obscure names wasn‚Äôt my favorite.

Gotta echo Barry and Andrzej today. Kudos on the double pangram, but way too many hoops to set there. Started out pretty easy. Then I got very bogged down in all the proper names. Now I know how y‚Äôall feel. RIPA, KOBE and LENIN I knew. ZINN, ELIA, EAZYE, REDD, MARLO, DOERR, RENATO, and DOLAN I had to get on crosses, and on the last four guess the crossing letter.  Guessed right, but guessed wrong on JFK and JCCAR which I couldn‚Äôt remember but thought was right. So I had to flyspeck and Google to see if  I was right on all my guesses (I‚Äôm not too proud to do that) until I finally got there. Wasn‚Äôt too thrilled with some of the clues either‚Äîhoppi-ness? Disappearing ink vessel? Is a driver a SELLER? Is QUIDPROQUO ‚Äúforeign‚Äù or just Latin? Again a stretchy clue or two is OK with me especially if it‚Äôs otherwise amusing but these didn‚Äôt thrill me. I didn‚Äôt mind ‚ÄúBoos‚Äù so much and a couple of bonus points for Star Wars and Plato. But overall a bridge too far for me.
Fun puzzle. I liked the long entries. Thanks.
I mean, doable with some guessing, but way too many proper names and no real clever clue. Felt like a Tuesday. Whatever.

Creators are getting way too lazy by using arcane trivia to make puzzles hard. It's OK when you can infer by other answers, but that wasn't the case today. All in all, a bit of a disappointment. Feel like I wasted my time today, with very little satisfaction when done.

These are what I'd call improper names.  Not good on any day to stuff a puzzle with showtime folks and a only a few clues worthy of the name(s). I want a challenging Saturday, with engaging clues that make me think, not just google.

Sorry, Blake, but I found this one tiresome.

Can I just say  RIGHT BRACE and not UPPER BOUND? Like, the very long set of 
Proper names {ELIA, ZINN, RFK, REDD, MARLO, RENATO, EAZY-E, KOBE} ends with it.

I appreciate the feat of construction, but if you're going to stuff the gaps with names and trivia clearly meant for a US audience, I'd rather just skip this whole slog and fill in the trivia using google.

 VEZ/ELIA/ZINN

I thought this was fun‚Äîgood mix of clever clues and really tricky trivia that I relied on crosses for. Had ‚Äúoniongrove‚Äù in for way too long but I‚Äôll blame it on it being 1 am now.

I feel that i'm about to kick a hornet's nest, and at least three inner voices are crying, Why, Kelp, why? But i've been wondering for a while, so ask i must.

Why is it that some international solvers complain that the NYT puzzle contains so/too many US cultural references? It is a puzzle published in a US paper. 

As a northwesterner living two hours from the Pacific Ocean, i am often baffled by New York and East Coast references from 3,000 miles away that i can't possibly know, but i accept that the puzzle is published in New York. And i learn the words over time. TIL there is an RFK bridge.

Some years ago i really tried to conquer the British type of crossword we in the US call an acrostic. I played the ones in British papers. There were a LOT of British cultural references on top of a wide array of wordplay patterns that i apparently could not crack. I'd fill in at most six or ten words and then admit defeat. But it didn't occur to me to complain that the puzzles were too British?

A puzzle that uses all the letters of the alphabet twice? It reminds me of an obit I read yesterday in the Times about a translator working on books by an author who wrote a whole book without any vowel E in it and another book with only vowels Es. Did you see it?

Sorry, I finished the puzzle (with a little help) but I'm still confused about CAB DRIVER?/WINE SELLER????

UPPERBOUND???

Dare I say it? I had to look up a lot of the US-specific proper nouns to solve this one, which took the enjoyment out of it a bit. Respect the double pangram, but overall just a bit too trivia-based and not enough cleverness for my taste.

Double pangram made this too cute by half. Naticks abound. Wine seller ... English words, sure. Is it really a thing? Plus isn't "Cab" an abbreviation? 

Pretty sure "loll" isn't an abbreviation but "veg" is. Clueing conventions out the window. 

Did I already mention multiple obscure names that defy linguistic norms? No. It's like they were the product of a google search that then became the clue. What can I use to get some Q's and K's? How about some Greenlandic proper nouns. 

Really not a fan. This almost felt mean-spirited.

This seemed easier than Friday‚Äôs puzzle until I hit the MARLO/DOERR crossing. I was annoyed to not know MARLO Kelly because (1) I used to be able to remember without difficulty the names of the actors and actresses we saw in movies and TV shows; (2) we don‚Äôt watch nearly as many movies and shows as we did back then, but the names of the people associated with the movies and shows barely register; and (3) one of the few shows we‚Äôve watched in the last year is ‚Äú3 Body Problem.‚Äù

I didn‚Äôt know the title in the clue for DOERR, though I have heard of his earlier novel ‚ÄúAll the Light We Cannot See‚Äù (which sounds interesting).

That O is about as close to a Natick as I can remember seeing in some time, in part because ‚ÄúKelly‚Äù could have been the actress‚Äôs first name or last name. 

I tried the most likely letters there and still didn‚Äôt get the gold star until I noticed that I c mistyped QUID PRO QUO. That‚Äôs a frustrating way to finish a puzzle. 

I didn‚Äôt notice the double pangram while solving, but I rarely pay attention to that sort of thing. It seems to be a pointless stunt unless the constructor takes it as far as, say, Trenton Charlson took his Z obsession. (‚ÄúSnoozefest,‚Äù 10/3/21).

I didn‚Äôt like the plethora of cross-reference clues. But it was fun to briefly imagine the [Outdoor setting for Plato‚Äôs Academy] as OLIVE Garden. And I feel pretty smug about knowing how to pronounce the Dutch soccer club‚Äôs name. Overall, a pretty good puzzle.

Most of this was pretty easy but the upper right was a terrible experience for me.  Unknown after unknown crossing other unknowns.  I finally yanked Zinn out of the neural recesses and managed to finish up without errors.

None of it was particularly fun.  There was really too much specialized knowledge in this one and the cluing seemed unremarkable.

ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÇÔ∏è

Perfectly engineered to be literally impossible for me to do without lookups, or even with lookups.

I finally went to Check Puzzle, a last resort.

I did get UPPERBOUND, and I do know some math, but I certainly don't see it as "the end of a set".  I'm prepared to be educated, but that just doesn't sound real to me.

KORMA and ROTI in the same section of the puzzle made for a difficult area for those unfamiliar with Indian food.

RCCAR vs jCCAR with the cross of RFK and jFK.  Pretty tough, and I have never heard of an RCCAR.  What is that?

SWEETIEPIES for [Boos]?  Unintelligible.  If this weren't a non-theme puzzle, I'd swear there were some missing letters or extra letters or some Thursday kind of devilry.

I imagine if I read Wordplay, I'll get some answers, but this was a virtually insolvable for me.  

I am really astonished, but not surprised that there are those who casually called this easy.

Ok, I still don't have a clue of [Boos] and SWEETIEPIE.

Unless someone can come up with something, I am going to officially consider this the worst clue/answer I've ever seen in the NYT puzzle.  

Or any puzzle, frankly.

Maybe someday we can have a puzzle which is just entirely proper names.

Most times people comment on this, I hadn't really noticed.

This one was just a slap in the face.

I honestly don't think anyone producing this puzzle has the slightest idea of what a set is, or what an upper bound is.  

Just one of many jarringly bad clue/answer pairs, beyond the clutter of proper names.

QUIDPROQUO from [Foreign exchange?]  We've literally absorbed the term into English directly from Latin.  Latin isn't so much foreign as it is fundamental.  It Latin really a foreign language if it's not spoken any longer?

16A.  Google seems to imply it was written by Charles Lamb.  Who  is Elia?

ICEHOLE for "Opening on a frozen lake"  Well, yeah, but a frozen lake is made of ice, so obviously a hole in it is going to be an hole in the ice.  But that only makes it an "icehole" in a really trivial sense.  That's like saying "I'm going to use this shovel to dig a dirthole."

OTRA VEZ.  I guess even though I grew up in an Hispanic area, I must have missed it over and over.

ORAJEL...I don't have the will to go on with this.  Every time I go back to the puzzle I find another frustratingly meaningless answer.
I saw ICEHOLE at 39A and immediately thought of the Michael Keaton movie ‚ÄúJohnny Dangerously‚Äù.
Saturday or not, that‚Äôs no excuse for three naticks.

The [Foreign exchange?} clue is excellent. I chuckled at [Exhibit hoppi-ness?] and also liked [Cab driver?].

The proper names, if not outright known to me, were all easy in the crossings, Anthony DOERR was a gimme for me and, of course, I know the bridge. But i can certainly see how those would be tricky for others.

I just finished a book and was wondering what to read next, so I was happy to be reminded of Cloud Cuckoo Land.  All The Light We Cannot See was a favorite, so this was a perfect time to see Anthony DOERR in the puzzle.

Nice puzzle, but I found two clues were iffy (others have noted this). Is QUID PRO QUO really "foreign"? I thought maybe it was because "quid" can mean "pound" (as in money) in that foreign land of UK, and "money" relates to "(currency) exchange," but no. Latin isn't really a foreign language (to me), because "foreign" firstly is another country one might visit, and that's not an option for the Roman Empire.

The other iffy one for me was WINE SELLER. Many jobs in the wine business could be construed as "driving" a cab(ernet), but the seller ain't one of 'em.
There is no double-z word in the puzzle. Not in the right corner or anywhere else. I think you mean Q J X--not Q J Z.

That is, I kept running into walls.  Vague cluing and no-knows (11) would freeze me, and I‚Äôd go somewhere else and freeze and flee again.  After ACRE / CENTRAL PARK right at the start, I thought I‚Äôd be gamboling through the box ‚Äì hah!  

Much lateral thinking and making educated guesses ‚Äì things my brain lives for ‚Äì were called on.  I just kept pinballing around, and answers would come, sometimes in dribs, other times followed by mini-splats, and always with gratitude.

Hard work, but the kind I like.

Lovely wordplay clues: [Foreign exchange] for QUID PRO QUO, [Boos] for SWEETIEPIES, and [Sprinkle with oil, say] for BLESS.   I also liked ERR crossing ERR in the middle east, because that's what my solve felt like often.  And, as with Thursday‚Äôs puzzle, I was strurck by the profusion of schwa-enders (8).  

I hope for a steep climb on Saturdays, and your obstacle course was just that, Blake.  Thank you!

"Thou preparest a table before me in the presence of mine enemies: thou anointest my head with oil; my cup runneth over."

Well, I thoroughly enjoyed this puzzle, especially the doubling of the Js, Xs, and Qs.  I loved QUID PRO QUO and loved its clue ("Foreign exchange") even more.

But I come to sing the praises of the double-V: OLIVE GROVE.  As a long-time student of Plato, I've heard again and again the phrase "the GROVEs of Academe", but I had never bother to investigate it further, other than knowing that Plato created his school in the suburb of Athens known as Academe, hence the origin of our term "academy".

In today's post-puzzle research, I learned that the phrase has its origin in an epistle of the Latin poet Horace: "Atque inter silvas Academi quaerere verum" ("...and to seek the truth in the groves of Academe...").  It was then popularized in the modern world in the novel "The Groves of Academe", a biting satire about the academic world by Mary McCarthy, in 1951.

I had never thought about what kind of trees were growing in that grove, but Aristophanes confirms our constructor's assertion in "The Clouds", referring to the "Academy, under the sacred OLIVE-trees" as a place where well-born youth could exercise their bodies to become decent Athenian gentlemen.

So, a fine puzzle, and a lovely opportunity to enhance my knowledge of the Classical world. Thanks, Blake Slonecker.

I managed to get within one letter of cracking this, and if I‚Äôd realized it was a double pangram then maybe ZINN/VEZ would have not caused me to say stop with the guessing. So, a serious puzzle, a Saturday struggle.

I just loved this puzzle! Got the jingle at around 80 percent of average solve time (give or take) as follows: the first 1/3 seemed hopeless, the second 1/3 entailed chipping away, and the last 1/3 flowed.

If Merriam-Webster included a comprehensive listing of English language slang, past and present, it would probably be at least as large as the unabridged OED. Probably much bigger.

SWEETIEPIE did baffle me, though. I got it entirely from the crosses, then sat and stared at it a while before the thought of BOO being a term of endearment slowly and painfully shouldered itself into my brain. I knew it was right, but it didn't make me happy.

Charles Lamb's pseudonym was "Elia," and so the clue is correct just as "Twain" would be for any clue quoting Samuel Clemens, but there's a difference: Lamb (and his sister) only used the pseudonym for two books of essays, and their public personas were still Charles and Mary Lamb, whereas Clemens essentially became "Mark Twain" both on the page and in person. 

Xwordinfo shows that others have clued Elia similarly to this one, including Jeff Chen, not reflecting that Elia is merely a pseudonym. It made me think that the constructors and editors don't know that "Elia" is "Lamb." You have to go back to 2014, and before that 2011, to find a work of Lamb's clued as an essay by this "pen name," although several others including Sam Ezersky have played with the pseudonym ["Lamb, by another name"]. Still, it's easy to insert "pen name" into the clue to provide clarification, just so we all know there wasn't an essayist named Elia.

The quotation is the last line of Lamb's "All F00l's Day" -- which I just read out of curiosity and have no taste for: its highfalutin pseudo-Elizabethan prose set my teeth on edge -- and talk about Naticks -- the essay is full of arcane references that were likely only slightly less obscure to readers of the early 19th century. But YMMV.

Many years ago, when I was part of a team of lawyers representing the Winooski 44, a group activists arrested for sitting in in our senior senator's office, I had the chance to meet Howard ZINN. Very cordial and willing to help, and his testimony was a seminar on how political movements make change happen. It was a pleasure. https://www.upi.com/Archives/1984/11/17/Freedom-for-members-of-the-Winooski-44/2330469515600/ Numerous names that were obscure to me, at least. Rappers are a given, but DOLAN, ELIA, REDD, MARLO, RENATO? No idea. I was a bit undecided as to whether they were talking about the renaming of the Triborough Bridge or the Tappan Zee, but I do remember seeing the RFK signs on my visits through the city. Still came in closer to my best than my average. SWEETIEPIES? Any ideas? Thanks!

Solved it unaided in 45 minutes, despite not knowing most of the names. Finally understood "Cab driver?" and entered WINESELLER to finish the puzzle.

As a mathematician, I got UPPERBOUND easily enough, despite "End of a set, in mathematics" being a bit wonky.

Really amazing collection of entries here. Puzzle of the year material!

To quote the late great Rodney Dangerfield -

I feel like I just gave birth.    



To an accountant.

Got the scrabble reference as I was solving, and enjoyed it.

Agree that there were too many proper nouns and crosses thereof.  I happened to know most of them, or could make an educated guess (DOLAN / RENATO).  

Still, I was stuck with one mistake for a couple minutes.  Finally, decided to look at the answer, figuring it must have been one of the name crosses.  Turns out I had AXeS instead of AXIS, and wasn't even checking there.  Had been trying to figure out how a ROs√© would pair with KORMA--seems tasty enough.

I found this to be a mostly fun and smooth Saturday, a little easier than yesterday, but not lamentably easy*.

That said, I‚Äôm sure some people will be turned off by the concentration of trivia in a couple spots ‚Äî in particular, RENATO/ORAJEL/EAZYE and MARLO/DOERR.

Neither of those spots slowed me down much (I found the crucial ‚ÄúO‚Äù in both cases to be inferable enough once I had all the other letters filled in), but I have to say I did find the inclusion of so much corporate branding (ORAJEL, ERASERMATE, DIETPEPSI, and arguably EAZYE, even if it‚Äôs not strictly a ‚Äúcorporate brand‚Äù) to be rather crass, especially in a single section of the puzzle.

@Francis

I am giving a lot of leeway to say that a least upper bound is a kind of end to a particular kind of set, a subset of the real line.  Here the use of "end of the set" is in colloquial English and not in mathematical English and the answer is in mathematical language, but I think that is fair for a challenging puzzle.  But even in this situation, the "upper bound" could be any number to the right of this set and does not connote the "end" point of the set.

@Francis

As I said, I am giving leeway.

For a particular class of sets, subsets of the real line, one often pictures them on the real axis which goes from -infinity to infinity in a left to right direction.  If we drew a set on this line, then one could imagine (with leeway) the leftmost point (for the mathematically picky, the greatest lower bound) and the rightmost point (least upper bound) as "ends" of the set.  

Actually you write "end" point and, indeed, "endpoint" is a mathematical term for the leftmost and rightmost points of an interval in the real line.
